Hi @poxvoculi , As per your comment here. I have looked the code of gmm_ops.py. I found that the input provided to the linalg_ops.matrix_inverse is not invertible in line inverse = linalg_ops.matrix_inverse(cov + self._min_var). I propose to calculate a pseudo matrix inverse in place of matrix inverse. Following code should work in its place:-

s,u,v=np.linalg.svd(cov + self._min_var)
inverse = math_ops.matmul(array_ops.transpose(v), math_ops.matmul(array_ops.diag(math_ops.pow(s,-1)),array_ops.transpose(u)))

I believe this is equivalent to numpy.linalg.pinv

It would be much better to provide a pseudo_matrix_inverse in linalg_ops.

Please look into it.

body:
Hi @poxvoculi , As per your comment [here](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/7784#issuecomment-282081517). I have looked the code of [gmm_ops.py](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/r1.0/tensorflow/contrib/factorization/python/ops/gmm_ops.py). I found that the input provided to the `linalg_ops.matrix_inverse` is not invertible in line `inverse = linalg_ops.matrix_inverse(cov + self._min_var)`. I propose to calculate a pseudo matrix inverse in place of matrix inverse. Following code should work in its place:-
```
s,u,v=np.linalg.svd(cov + self._min_var)
inverse = math_ops.matmul(array_ops.transpose(v), math_ops.matmul(array_ops.diag(math_ops.pow(s,-1)),array_ops.transpose(u)))
```
I believe this is equivalent to `numpy.linalg.pinv`

It would be much better to provide a `pseudo_matrix_inverse` in `linalg_ops`.

Please look into it.
